document.docAuthor: Oliveira, Fábio G. L., Cipola, Nikolas G. & Almeida, Eduardo A. B.
document.docTitle: Salina hamadae Oliveira¹ & Cipola² & Almeida¹ 2020, sp.n.
document.masterDocTitle: Systematics and biogeography of Salina MacGillivray (Collembola: Entomobryoidea), with emphasis on the species groups in the New World

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Systematics and biogeography of Salina MacGillivray (Collembola: Entomobryoidea), with emphasis on the species groups in the New World

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 17. Collophore chaetotaxy of
Salina
spp.: (A–B),
Salina brasiliana
sp.n.
: (A), anterior side; (B), lateral and posterior side. (C–D),
S. bellinii
sp.n.
: (C), anterior side; (D), lateral and posterior side. (E), complete chaetotaxy (lateral view) of
S. bicolor
sp.n.
(F–G),
S. hamadae
sp.n.
: (F), anterior side; (G), lateral and posterior side.

subSubSection.paragraph: Body and legs with blue spots; Ant I with 9 mac; cephalic groove only with ciliate chaetae; Th II–Abd I with 1–2, 3, 2 central mac, respectively; Abd III with 3 lateral mac ( am6 , pm6 , p6 ); Abd IV with 10 central mac ( A3 and A4 present, A3p and A5 absent) and 9 lateral mac; collophore with 8 anterior, 5 posterior and 12 lateral flap chaetae; trochanteral organ with 16 spine-like chaetae; manubrial plate with 3 chaetae.

Holotype ♀ on slide (COLLE 044/INPA): Brazil , Santa Catarina , Urubici municipality, Private Reserve of Natural Patrimony (RPPN), “Portal das Nascentes”, 28°03’02”S ; 49°22’44”W , Atlantic Forest ,
1020 m
,
18.viii.2013
, Pitfall-trap , JMC Nascimento & N Hamada coll.
Paratypes on slides (COLLE 044A-W/INPA): 2 ♂ and 21 ♀ and 14 in alcohol, same data as holotype
.

Total length (head + trunk) of holotype 2.51 mm. Specimens pale white with blue pigments on Ant I–IV, slightly on anterior head, intersegmental areas of antennae and legs; lateral of Th II to Abd IV; presence of irregular spots from Abd III – IV; Eyepatches black ( Figure 9D ).

Dorsal chaetotaxy. Th II with 1 ‘m’ mac ( m7 ); 1–2 ‘p’ mac ( p1a , p2 ), p2 present or absent. Th III with 1 ‘a’ mac ( a7? ); 1 ‘m’ mac ( m7 ); 3 ‘p’ mac ( p1i , p2–3 ) ( Figure 12D ). Abd I with 2 ‘m’ mac ( m3 , m4 ) ( Figure 13D ). Abd III with 2 ‘m’ mac ( am6 , pm6 ); 1 ‘p’ mac ( p6 ) ( Figure 14B ); Abd IV with 4 ‘A’ mac ( A1 , A3 , A4 , A6 ); 1 ‘Ae’ mac ( Ae1 ); 3 ‘B’ mac ( B3–5 ); 1 ‘Be’ mac ( Be1 ); 1 ‘C’ mac ( C1) ; 3 ‘E’ mac ( E1 , E2 , E4 ); 3 ‘F’ mac ( F1–F3 ); 3 ‘Fe’ mac ( Fe1–2 , Fe6 ); posterior side with 3 sens type IV ( ps and two unnamed) ( Figure 14E ). Abd V with 3 ‘a’ mac ( a0 , a3 , a5 ); 3 ‘m’ mac ( m2–3 , m5 ); and 5 ‘p’ mac ( p1–5 ) ( Figure 15D ).

Appendages. Trochanteral organ with 16 smooth spine-like chaetae ( Figure 16D ). Collophore anterior side with 4 subapical mac of equal length, and 4 proximal smooth mic; posterior side with 1 apical ciliated mic and 4 subapical smooth chaetae; lateral flap formula 4(s), 4(m), 4(i) smooth chaetae ( Figures 17 F-G). Manubrial plate with 3 chaetae ( Figure 19C ). Mucro with 3 teeth ( d1 , ap , v1 ) ( Figure 19F ).
The epithet honors our entomologist and friend Dr. Neusa Hamada, collector of the specimens.

Salina hamadae
sp.n.
resembles
S. serrana
sp.n.
by body and legs with blue spots, Ant I with more than 6 mac, Abd I with 2 central mac, Abd IV with at least 10 central mac, and mucro with 4 teeth. However,
S. hamadae
sp.n.
differs of
S. serrana
sp.n.
in chaetotaxy of the Th II–III with p1a and p1i mac, respectively (both absent in
S. serrana
sp.n.
), Abd III with 3 lateral mac next to m5 bothriotrichum ( 2 in
S. serrana
sp.n.
), and Abd IV devoid of A3p and A5 mac (present in
S. serrana
sp.n.
)

Salina hamadae
sp.n.
also differs by Ant I with 9 mac ( 7 in
S. serrana
sp.n.
), trochanteral organ with 16 spine-like chaetae ( 13 in
S. serrana
sp.n.
), manubrial plate with 3 chaetae ( 2 in
S. serrana
sp.n.
), and collophore with 8 anterior chaetae (4 mac) and 12 chaetae in three rows on lateral flap, while
S. serrana
sp.n.
has 13 anterior chaetae (3 mac) and lateral flap with 20 chaetae in 4 rows. For additional information, refer to Table 2 .
